017package com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.pure.ipt_hq;
018
019import com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.pure.FloatColors;
020import com.github.tommyettinger.digital.BitConversion;
021import com.github.tommyettinger.digital.MathTools;
022import com.github.tommyettinger.random.EnhancedRandom;
023
024import java.util.Random;
025
026/**
027 * Contains code for manipulating colors as {@code int} and packed {@code float} values in the IPT color space.
028 * IPT has more perceptually-uniform handling of hue than some other color spaces, like YCwCm, and this version goes
029 * further than {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.pure.ipt the IPT package} by performing gamma correction and all the
030 * complex exponential adjustments to various components that the original IPT paper used. In most regards, this is a
031 * more thoroughly-constructed color space than YCwCm, but YCwCm may still be useful because of how it maps to aesthetic
032 * components of color. See {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)} for docs on the I, P, and T channels.
033 */
034public class ColorTools {
035        /**
036         * Gets a packed float representation of a color given as 4 float components, here, I (intensity or lightness), P
037         * (protan, a chromatic component ranging from greenish to reddish), T (tritan, a chromatic component ranging from
038         * bluish to yellowish), and A (alpha or opacity). Intensity should be between 0 and 1, inclusive, with 0 used for
039         * very dark colors (almost only black), and 1 used for very light colors (almost only white). Protan and tritan
040         * range from 0.0 to 1.0, with grayscale results when both are about 0.5. There's some aesthetic value in changing
041         * just one chroma value. When protan is high and tritan is low, the color is more purple/magenta, when both are low
042         * it is more bluish, when tritan is high and protan is low, the color tends to be greenish, and when both are high
043         * it tends to be orange. When protan and tritan are both near 0.5f, the color is closer to gray.  Alpha is the
044         * multiplicative opacity of the color, and acts like RGBA's alpha.
045         * <br>
046         * This method bit-masks the resulting color's byte values, so any values can technically be given to this as
047         * intensity, protan, and tritan, but they will only be reversible from the returned float color to the original I,
048         * P, and T values if the original values were in the range that {@link #intensity(float)}, {@link #protan(float)},
049         * and {@link #tritan(float)} return. You can use {@link #inGamut(float, float, float)} to check if a given set of
050         * I, P, and T values is in-gamut, that is, it can be converted to and from an RGB color without going out of the
051         * valid range. If you just want to enforce that a color is in-gamut, you can use
052         * {@link #limitToGamut(float, float, float, float)}, which takes the same parameters this method does, or
053         * {@link #limitToGamut(float)} if you already have a packed float color that could be out-of-gamut.
054         *
055         * @param intens     0f to 1f, intensity or I component of IPT, with 0.5f meaning "no change" and 1f brightening
056         * @param protan     0f to 1f, protan or P component of IPT, with 1f more orange, red, or magenta
057         * @param tritan     0f to 1f, tritan or T component of IPT, with 1f more green, yellow, or red
058         * @param alpha      0f to 1f, 0f makes the color transparent and 1f makes it opaque 
059         * @return a float encoding a color with the given properties
060         */
061        public static float ipt(float intens, float protan, float tritan, float alpha) {
062                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (alpha * 255) << 24 & 0xFE000000) | ((int) (tritan * 255) << 16 & 0xFF0000)
063                                | ((int) (protan * 255) << 8 & 0xFF00) | ((int) (intens * 255) & 0xFF));
064        }
065
066
067        /**
068         * Used when converting from RGB to IPT, as an intermediate step.
069         * @param component one of the LMS channels to be converted to LMS Prime
070         * @return an LMS Prime channel value, which can be converted to IPT
071         */
072        private static float forwardTransform(final float component) {
073                return (float)Math.pow(component, 0.43f);
074        }
075
076        /**
077         * Used when converting from IPT to RGB, as an intermediate step.
078         * @param component one of the LMS Prime channels to be converted to LMS
079         * @return an LMS channel value, which can be converted to RGB
080         */
081        private static float reverseTransform(final float component) {
082                return Math.copySign((float)Math.pow(Math.abs(component), 2.3256f), component);
083        }
084
085        /**
086         * Used when given non-linear sRGB inputs to make them linear, approximating with gamma 2.0.
087         * @param component any non-linear channel of a color, to be made linear
088         * @return a linear version of component
089         */
090        private static float forwardGamma(final float component) {
091                return component * component;
092        }
093
094        /**
095         * Used to return from a linear, gamma-corrected input to an sRGB, non-linear output, using gamma 2.0.
096         * @param component a linear channel of a color, to be made non-linear
097         * @return a non-linear version of component
098         */
099        private static float reverseGamma(final float component) {
100                return (float)Math.sqrt(component);
101        }
102
103
104        /**
105         * Converts a packed float color in the format produced by {@link ColorTools#ipt(float, float, float, float)} to an RGBA8888 int.
106         * This format of int can be used with Pixmap and in some other places in libGDX.
107         * @param packed a packed float color, as produced by {@link ColorTools#ipt(float, float, float, float)}
108         * @return an RGBA8888 int color
109         */
110        public static int toRGBA8888(final float packed)
111        {
112                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
113                final float i = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
114                final float p = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
115                final float t = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
116                final float l = reverseTransform(i + 0.097569f * p + 0.205226f * t);
117                final float m = reverseTransform(i + -0.11388f * p + 0.133217f * t);
118                final float s = reverseTransform(i + 0.032615f * p + -0.67689f * t);
119                final int r = (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(5.432622f * l + -4.67910f * m + 0.246257f * s, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
120                final int g = (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-1.10517f * l + 2.311198f * m + -0.20588f * s, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
121                final int b = (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(0.028104f * l + -0.19466f * m + 1.166325f * s, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
122                return r << 24 | g << 16 | b << 8 | (decoded & 0xfe000000) >>> 24 | decoded >>> 31;
123        }
124
125        /**
126         * Converts a packed float color in the format produced by {@link ColorTools#ipt(float, float, float, float)}
127         * to a packed float in RGBA format.
128         * This format of float can be used with the standard SpriteBatch and in some other places in libGDX.
129         * @param packed a packed float color, as produced by {@link ColorTools#ipt(float, float, float, float)}
130         * @return a packed float color as RGBA
131         */
132        public static float toRGBA(final float packed)
133        {
134                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
135                final float i = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
136                final float p = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
137                final float t = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
138                final float l = reverseTransform(i + 0.097569f * p + 0.205226f * t);
139                final float m = reverseTransform(i + -0.11388f * p + 0.133217f * t);
140                final float s = reverseTransform(i + 0.032615f * p + -0.67689f * t);
141                final int r = (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(5.432622f * l + -4.67910f * m + 0.246257f * s, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
142                final int g = (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-1.10517f * l + 2.311198f * m + -0.20588f * s, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
143                final int b = (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(0.028104f * l + -0.19466f * m + 1.166325f * s, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
144                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(r | g << 8 | b << 16 | (decoded & 0xfe000000));
145        }
146
147        /**
148         * Takes a color encoded as an RGBA8888 int and converts to a packed float in the IPT format this uses.
149         * @param rgba an int with the channels (in order) red, green, blue, alpha; should have 8 bits per channel
150         * @return a packed float as IPT, which this class can use
151         */
152        public static float fromRGBA8888(final int rgba) {
153                final float r = forwardGamma((rgba >>> 24) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f);
154                final float g = forwardGamma((rgba >>> 16 & 0xFF) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f);
155                final float b = forwardGamma((rgba >>> 8 & 0xFF) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f);
156                final float l = forwardTransform(0.313921f * r + 0.639468f * g + 0.0465970f * b);
157                final float m = forwardTransform(0.151693f * r + 0.748209f * g + 0.1000044f * b);
158                final float s = forwardTransform(0.017753f * r + 0.109468f * g + 0.8729690f * b);
159                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(
160                                      Math.min(Math.max((int)((0.4000f * l + 0.4000f * m + 0.2000f * s       ) * 255.999f), 0), 255)
161                                                | Math.min(Math.max((int)((2.2275f * l - 2.4255f * m + 0.1980f * s + 0.5f) * 255.999f), 0), 255) << 8
162                                                | Math.min(Math.max((int)((0.4028f * l + 0.1786f * m - 0.5814f * s + 0.5f) * 255.999f), 0), 255) << 16
163                                                | (rgba & 0xFE) << 24);
164        }
165
166        /**
167         * Takes a color encoded as an RGBA8888 packed float and converts to a packed float in the IPT format this uses.
168         * @param packed a packed float in RGBA8888 format, with A in the MSB and R in the LSB
169         * @return a packed float as IPT, which this class can use
170         */
171        public static float fromRGBA(final float packed) {
172                final int abgr = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
173                final float r = forwardGamma((abgr & 0xFF) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f);
174                final float g = forwardGamma((abgr >>> 8 & 0xFF) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f);
175                final float b = forwardGamma((abgr >>> 16 & 0xFF) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f);
176                final float l = forwardTransform(0.313921f * r + 0.639468f * g + 0.0465970f * b);
177                final float m = forwardTransform(0.151693f * r + 0.748209f * g + 0.1000044f * b);
178                final float s = forwardTransform(0.017753f * r + 0.109468f * g + 0.8729690f * b);
179                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(
180                                      Math.min(Math.max((int)((0.4000f * l + 0.4000f * m + 0.2000f * s       ) * 255.999f), 0), 255)
181                                                | Math.min(Math.max((int)((2.2275f * l - 2.4255f * m + 0.1980f * s + 0.5f) * 255.999f), 0), 255) << 8
182                                                | Math.min(Math.max((int)((0.4028f * l + 0.1786f * m - 0.5814f * s + 0.5f) * 255.999f), 0), 255) << 16
183                                                | (abgr & 0xFE000000));
184        }
185
186        /**
187         * Takes RGBA components from 0.0 to 1.0 each and converts to a packed float in the IPT format this uses.
188         * @param r red, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
189         * @param g green, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
190         * @param b blue, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
191         * @param a alpha, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
192         * @return a packed float as IPT, which this class can use
193         */
194        public static float fromRGBA(float r, float g, float b, final float a) {
195                r = forwardGamma(r);
196                g = forwardGamma(g);
197                b = forwardGamma(b);
198                final float l = forwardTransform(0.313921f * r + 0.639468f * g + 0.0465970f * b);
199                final float m = forwardTransform(0.151693f * r + 0.748209f * g + 0.1000044f * b);
200                final float s = forwardTransform(0.017753f * r + 0.109468f * g + 0.8729690f * b);
201                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(
202                                          Math.min(Math.max((int)((0.4000f * l + 0.4000f * m + 0.2000f * s       ) * 255.999f), 0), 255)
203                                                | Math.min(Math.max((int)((2.2275f * l - 2.4255f * m + 0.1980f * s + 0.5f) * 255.999f), 0), 255) << 8
204                                                | Math.min(Math.max((int)((0.4028f * l + 0.1786f * m - 0.5814f * s + 0.5f) * 255.999f), 0), 255) << 16
205                                                | ((int)(a * 255f) << 24 & 0xFE000000));
206        }
207
208        /**
209         * Gets the red channel value of the given encoded color, as an int ranging from 0 to 255, inclusive.
210         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}
211         * @return an int from 0 to 255, inclusive, representing the red channel value of the given encoded color
212         */
213        public static int redInt(final float encoded)
214        {
215                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
216                final float i = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
217                final float p = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
218                final float t = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
219                final float l = reverseTransform(i + 0.097569f * p + 0.205226f * t);
220                final float m = reverseTransform(i + -0.11388f * p + 0.133217f * t);
221                final float s = reverseTransform(i + 0.032615f * p + -0.67689f * t);
222                return (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(5.432622f * l + -4.67910f * m + 0.246257f * s, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
223        }
224
225        /**
226         * Gets the green channel value of the given encoded color, as an int ranging from 0 to 255, inclusive.
227         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}
228         * @return an int from 0 to 255, inclusive, representing the green channel value of the given encoded color
229         */
230        public static int greenInt(final float encoded)
231        {
232                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
233                final float i = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
234                final float p = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
235                final float t = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
236                final float l = reverseTransform(i + 0.097569f * p + 0.205226f * t);
237                final float m = reverseTransform(i + -0.11388f * p + 0.133217f * t);
238                final float s = reverseTransform(i + 0.032615f * p + -0.67689f * t);
239                return (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-1.10517f * l + 2.311198f * m + -0.20588f * s, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
240        }
241
242        /**
243         * Gets the blue channel value of the given encoded color, as an int ranging from 0 to 255, inclusive.
244         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}
245         * @return an int from 0 to 255, inclusive, representing the blue channel value of the given encoded color
246         */
247        public static int blueInt(final float encoded)
248        {
249                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
250                final float i = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
251                final float p = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
252                final float t = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
253                final float l = reverseTransform(i + 0.097569f * p + 0.205226f * t);
254                final float m = reverseTransform(i + -0.11388f * p + 0.133217f * t);
255                final float s = reverseTransform(i + 0.032615f * p + -0.67689f * t);
256                return (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(0.028104f * l + -0.19466f * m + 1.166325f * s, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
257        }
258
259        /**
260         * Gets the alpha channel value of the given encoded color, as an even int ranging from 0 to 254, inclusive. Because
261         * of how alpha is stored in libGDX, no odd-number values are possible for alpha.
262         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}
263         * @return an even int from 0 to 254, inclusive, representing the alpha channel value of the given encoded color
264         */
265        public static int alphaInt(final float encoded)
266        {
267                return (BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) & 0xfe000000) >>> 24;
268        }
269
270        /**
271         * Gets the red channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
272         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}
273         * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the red channel value of the given encoded color
274         */
275        public static float red(final float encoded)
276        {
277                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
278                final float i = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
279                final float p = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
280                final float t = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
281                final float l = reverseTransform(i + 0.097569f * p + 0.205226f * t);
282                final float m = reverseTransform(i + -0.11388f * p + 0.133217f * t);
283                final float s = reverseTransform(i + 0.032615f * p + -0.67689f * t);
284                return reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(5.432622f * l + -4.67910f * m + 0.246257f * s, 0f), 1f));
285        }
286
287        /**
288         * Gets the green channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
289         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}
290         * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the green channel value of the given encoded color
291         */
292        public static float green(final float encoded)
293        {
294                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
295                final float i = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
296                final float p = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
297                final float t = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
298                final float l = reverseTransform(i + 0.097569f * p + 0.205226f * t);
299                final float m = reverseTransform(i + -0.11388f * p + 0.133217f * t);
300                final float s = reverseTransform(i + 0.032615f * p + -0.67689f * t);
301                return reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-1.10517f * l + 2.311198f * m + -0.20588f * s, 0f), 1f));
302        }
303
304        /**
305         * Gets the blue channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
306         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}
307         * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the blue channel value of the given encoded color
308         */
309        public static float blue(final float encoded)
310        {
311                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
312                final float i = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
313                final float p = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
314                final float t = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
315                final float l = reverseTransform(i + 0.097569f * p + 0.205226f * t);
316                final float m = reverseTransform(i + -0.11388f * p + 0.133217f * t);
317                final float s = reverseTransform(i + 0.032615f * p + -0.67689f * t);
318                return reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(0.028104f * l + -0.19466f * m + 1.166325f * s, 0f), 1f));
319        }
320
321        /**
322         * Gets the alpha channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
323         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}
324         * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the alpha channel value of the given encoded color
325         */
326        public static float alpha(final float encoded)
327        {
328                return ((BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) & 0xfe000000) >>> 24) * 0x1.020408p-8f;
329        }
330
331        /**
332         * Gets a color as an IPT packed float given floats representing hue, saturation, lightness, and opacity.
333         * All parameters should normally be between 0 and 1 inclusive, though any hue is tolerated (precision loss may
334         * affect the color if the hue is too large). A hue of 0 is red, progressively higher hue values go to orange,
335         * yellow, green, blue, and purple before wrapping around to red as it approaches 1. A saturation of 0 is grayscale,
336         * a saturation of 1 is brightly colored, and values close to 1 will usually appear more distinct than values close
337         * to 0, especially if the hue is different. A lightness of 0.001f or less is always black (also using a shortcut if
338         * this is the case, respecting opacity), while a lightness of 1f is white. Very bright colors are mostly in a band
339         * of high-saturation where lightness is 0.5f.
340         *
341         * @param hue        0f to 1f, color wheel position
342         * @param saturation 0f to 1f, 0f is grayscale and 1f is brightly colored
343         * @param lightness  0f to 1f, 0f is black and 1f is white
344         * @param opacity    0f to 1f, 0f is fully transparent and 1f is opaque
345         * @return a float encoding a color with the given properties
346         */
347        public static float floatGetHSL(float hue, float saturation, float lightness, float opacity) {
348                if (lightness <= 0.001f) {
349                        return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat((((int) (opacity * 255f) << 24) & 0xFE000000) | 0x7F7F00);
350                } else {
351                        return fromRGBA(FloatColors.hsl2rgb(hue, saturation, lightness, opacity));
352                }
353        }
354
355        /**
356         * Gets the saturation of the given encoded color, as a float ranging from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
357         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}
358         * @return the saturation of the color from 0.0 (a grayscale color; inclusive) to 1.0 (a bright color, inclusive)
359         */
360        public static float saturation(final float encoded) {
361                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
362                final float i = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
363                if(Math.abs(i - 0.5) > 0.495f) return 0f;
364                final float p = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
365                final float t = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
366                final float l = reverseTransform(i + 0.097569f * p + 0.205226f * t);
367                final float m = reverseTransform(i + -0.11388f * p + 0.133217f * t);
368                final float s = reverseTransform(i + 0.032615f * p + -0.67689f * t);
369                final float r = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(5.432622f * l + -4.67910f * m + 0.246257f * s, 0f), 1f));
370                final float g = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-1.10517f * l + 2.311198f * m + -0.20588f * s, 0f), 1f));
371                final float b = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(0.028104f * l + -0.19466f * m + 1.166325f * s, 0f), 1f));
372                float x, y, w;
373                if(g < b) {
374                        x = b;
375                        y = g;
376                }
377                else {
378                        x = g;
379                        y = b;
380                }
381                if(r < x) {
382                        w = r;
383                }
384                else {
385                        w = x;
386                        x = r;
387                }
388                return x - Math.min(w, y);
389        }
390
391        public static float lightness(final float encoded) {
392                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
393                final float i = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
394                final float p = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
395                final float t = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
396                final float l = reverseTransform(i + 0.097569f * p + 0.205226f * t);
397                final float m = reverseTransform(i + -0.11388f * p + 0.133217f * t);
398                final float s = reverseTransform(i + 0.032615f * p + -0.67689f * t);
399                final float r = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(5.432622f * l + -4.67910f * m + 0.246257f * s, 0f), 1f));
400                final float g = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-1.10517f * l + 2.311198f * m + -0.20588f * s, 0f), 1f));
401                final float b = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(0.028104f * l + -0.19466f * m + 1.166325f * s, 0f), 1f));
402
403                float x, y, w;
404                if(g < b) {
405                        x = b;
406                        y = g;
407                }
408                else {
409                        x = g;
410                        y = b;
411                }
412                if(r < x) {
413                        w = r;
414                }
415                else {
416                        w = x;
417                        x = r;
418                }
419                float d = x - Math.min(w, y);
420                return x * (1f - 0.5f * d / (x + 1e-10f));
421        }
422
423        /**
424         * Gets the hue of the given encoded color, as a float from 0f (inclusive, red and approaching orange if increased)
425         * to 1f (exclusive, red and approaching purple if decreased).
426         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}
427         * @return The hue of the color from 0.0 (red, inclusive) towards orange, then yellow, and
428         * eventually to purple before looping back to almost the same red (1.0, exclusive)
429         */
430        public static float hue(final float encoded) {
431                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
432                final float i = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
433                final float p = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
434                final float t = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
435                final float l = reverseTransform(i + 0.097569f * p + 0.205226f * t);
436                final float m = reverseTransform(i + -0.11388f * p + 0.133217f * t);
437                final float s = reverseTransform(i + 0.032615f * p + -0.67689f * t);
438                final float r = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(5.432622f * l + -4.67910f * m + 0.246257f * s, 0f), 1f));
439                final float g = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-1.10517f * l + 2.311198f * m + -0.20588f * s, 0f), 1f));
440                final float b = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(0.028104f * l + -0.19466f * m + 1.166325f * s, 0f), 1f));
441                float x, y, z, w;
442                if(g < b) {
443                        x = b;
444                        y = g;
445                        z = -1f;
446                        w = 2f / 3f;
447                }
448                else {
449                        x = g;
450                        y = b;
451                        z = 0f;
452                        w = -1f / 3f;
453                }
454                if(r < x) {
455                        z = w;
456                        w = r;
457                }
458                else {
459                        w = x;
460                        x = r;
461                }
462                float d = x - Math.min(w, y);
463                return Math.abs(z + (w - y) / (6f * d + 1e-10f));
464        }
465
466        /**
467         * The "intensity" of the given packed float in IPT format, which is like its lightness; ranges from 0.0f to
468         * 1.0f . You can edit the intensity of a color with {@link #lighten(float, float)} and
469         * {@link #darken(float, float)}.
470         *
471         * @param encoded a color encoded as a packed float, as by {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}
472         * @return the intensity value as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f
473         */
474        public static float intensity(final float encoded)
475        {
476                return (BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) & 0xff) / 255f;
477        }
478
479        /**
480         * The "protan" of the given packed float in IPT format, which when combined with tritan describes the
481         * hue and saturation of a color; ranges from 0f to 1f . If protan is 0f, the color will be cooler, more green or
482         * blue; if protan is 1f, the color will be warmer, from magenta to orange. You can edit the protan of a color with
483         * {@link #protanUp(float, float)} and {@link #protanDown(float, float)}.
484         * @param encoded a color encoded as a packed float, as by {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}
485         * @return the protan value as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f
486         */
487        public static float protan(final float encoded)
488        {
489                return ((BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) >>> 8 & 0xff)) / 255f;
490        }
491
492        /**
493         * The "tritan" of the given packed float in IPT format, which when combined with protan describes the
494         * hue and saturation of a color; ranges from 0f to 1f . If tritan is 0f, the color will be more "artificial", more
495         * blue or purple; if tritan is 1f, the color will be more "natural", from green to yellow to orange. You can edit
496         * the tritan of a color with {@link #tritanUp(float, float)} and {@link #tritanDown(float, float)}.
497         * @param encoded a color encoded as a packed float, as by {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}
498         * @return the tritan value as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f
499         */
500        public static float tritan(final float encoded)
501        {
502                return ((BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) >>> 16 & 0xff)) / 255f;
503        }
504
505        /**
506         * Gets a variation on the packed float color basis as another packed float that has its hue, saturation, lightness,
507         * and opacity adjusted by the specified amounts. Note that this edits the color in HSL space, not IPT_HQ! Takes
508         * floats representing the amounts of change to apply to hue, saturation, lightness, and opacity; these can be
509         * between -1f and 1f. Returns a float that can be used as a packed or encoded color. The float is
510         * likely to be different than the result of {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)} unless hue, saturation,
511         * lightness, and opacity are all 0. This won't allocate any objects.
512         * <br>
513         * The parameters this takes all specify additive changes for a color component, clamping the final values so they
514         * can't go above 1 or below 0, with an exception for hue, which can rotate around if lower or higher hues would be
515         * used. As an example, if you give this 0.4f for saturation, and the current color has saturation 0.7f, then the
516         * resulting color will have 1f for saturation. If you gave this -0.1f for saturation and the current color again
517         * has saturation 0.7f, then resulting color will have 0.6f for saturation.
518         *
519         * @param basis      a packed float color that will be used as the starting point to make the next color
520         * @param hue        -1f to 1f, the hue change that can be applied to the new float color (not clamped, wraps)
521         * @param saturation -1f to 1f, the saturation change that can be applied to the new float color
522         * @param light      -1f to 1f, the light/brightness change that can be applied to the new float color
523         * @param opacity    -1f to 1f, the opacity/alpha change that can be applied to the new float color
524         * @return a float encoding a variation of basis with the given changes
525         */
526        public static float toEditedFloat(float basis, float hue, float saturation, float light, float opacity) {
527                final int e = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(basis);
528                final float i = Math.min(Math.max(light + (e & 0xff) / 255f, 0f), 1f);
529                opacity = Math.min(Math.max(opacity + (e >>> 24 & 0xfe) * 0x1.020408p-8f, 0f), 1f);
530                if (i <= 0.001f)
531                        return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat((((int) (opacity * 255f) << 24) & 0xFE000000) | 0x808000);
532                final float p = ((e >>> 7 & 0x1fe) - 0xff) / 255f;
533                final float t = ((e >>> 15 & 0x1fe) - 0xff) / 255f;
534                final float l = reverseTransform(i + 0.097569f * p + 0.205226f * t);
535                final float m = reverseTransform(i + -0.11388f * p + 0.133217f * t);
536                final float s = reverseTransform(i + 0.032615f * p + -0.67689f * t);
537                final float r = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(5.432622f * l + -4.67910f * m + 0.246257f * s, 0f), 1f));
538                final float g = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-1.10517f * l + 2.311198f * m + -0.20588f * s, 0f), 1f));
539                final float b = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(0.028104f * l + -0.19466f * m + 1.166325f * s, 0f), 1f));
540                float x, y, z, w;
541                if(g < b) {
542                        x = b;
543                        y = g;
544                        z = -1f;
545                        w = 2f / 3f;
546                }
547                else {
548                        x = g;
549                        y = b;
550                        z = 0f;
551                        w = -1f / 3f;
552                }
553                if(r < x) {
554                        z = w;
555                        w = r;
556                }
557                else {
558                        w = x;
559                        x = r;
560                }
561                final float d = x - Math.min(w, y);
562                final float lum = x * (1f - 0.5f * d / (x + 1e-10f));
563                hue += Math.abs(z + (w - y) / (6f * d + 1e-10f)) + 1f;
564                saturation += (x - lum) / (Math.min(lum, 1f - lum) + 1e-10f);
565                return fromRGBA(FloatColors.hsl2rgb(hue - (int)hue, Math.min(Math.max(saturation, 0f), 1f), lum, opacity));
566        }
567
568        /**
569         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards white by change. While change should be between 0f (return
570         * start as-is) and 1f (return white), start should be a packed color, as from
571         * {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
572         * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp
573         * towards white. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and both
574         * chroma of start as-is. This method does not necessarily keep the resulting color in-gamut; after performing some
575         * changes with this or other component-editing methods (like {@link #protanUp(float, float)} or
576         * {@link #tritanDown(float, float)}), you may want to call {@link #limitToGamut(float)} to make sure the color can
577         * be rendered correctly.
578         *
579         * @see #darken(float, float) the counterpart method that darkens a float color
580         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
581         * @param change how much to go from start toward white, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to white
582         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and white
583         */
584        public static float lighten(final float start, final float change) {
585                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), i = s & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFFFF00;
586                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (i + (0xFF - i) * change) & 0xFF) | other);
587        }
588
589        /**
590         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards black by change. While change should be between 0f (return
591         * start as-is) and 1f (return black), start should be a packed color, as from
592         * {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
593         * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp
594         * towards white. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and both
595         * chroma of start as-is. This method does not necessarily keep the resulting color in-gamut; after performing some
596         * changes with this or other component-editing methods (like {@link #protanUp(float, float)} or
597         * {@link #tritanDown(float, float)}), you may want to call {@link #limitToGamut(float)} to make sure the color can
598         * be rendered correctly.
599         *
600         * @see #lighten(float, float) the counterpart method that lightens a float color
601         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
602         * @param change how much to go from start toward black, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to black
603         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and black
604         */
605        public static float darken(final float start, final float change) {
606                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), i = s & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFFFF00;
607                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (i * (1f - change)) & 0xFF) | other);
608        }
609
610        /**
611         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards a warmer color (orange to magenta) by change. While change
612         * should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully warmed), start should be a packed color, as from
613         * {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors,
614         * and is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to
615         * lerp towards a warmer color. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the
616         * alpha and intensity of start as-is.
617         * This method does not necessarily keep the resulting color in-gamut; after performing some changes with this or
618         * other component-editing methods (like {@link #lighten(float, float)} or {@link #tritanDown(float, float)}), you
619         * may want to call {@link #limitToGamut(float)} to make sure the color can be rendered correctly.
620         *
621         * @see #protanDown(float, float) the counterpart method that cools a float color
622         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
623         * @param change how much to warm start, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a warmer result
624         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a warmer color
625         */
626        public static float protanUp(final float start, final float change) {
627                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), p = s >>> 8 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFF00FF;
628                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (p + (0xFF - p) * change) << 8 & 0xFF00) | other);
629        }
630
631        /**
632         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards a cooler color (green to blue) by change. While change
633         * should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully cooled), start should be a packed color, as from
634         * {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
635         * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp
636         * towards a cooler color. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and
637         * intensity of start as-is.
638         * This method does not necessarily keep the resulting color in-gamut; after performing some changes with this or
639         * other component-editing methods (like {@link #lighten(float, float)} or {@link #tritanDown(float, float)}), you
640         * may want to call {@link #limitToGamut(float)} to make sure the color can be rendered correctly.
641         *
642         * @see #protanUp(float, float) the counterpart method that warms a float color
643         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
644         * @param change how much to cool start, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a cooler result
645         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a cooler color
646         */
647        public static float protanDown(final float start, final float change) {
648                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), p = s >>> 8 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFF00FF;
649                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (p * (1f - change)) & 0xFF) << 8 | other);
650        }
651
652        /**
653         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards a "natural" color (between green and orange) by change.
654         * While change should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully natural), start should be a packed color, as
655         * from {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary
656         * Colors, and is a little more efficient and clear than using
657         * {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards a more natural color. Unlike
658         * {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and intensity of start as-is.
659         * This method does not necessarily keep the resulting color in-gamut; after performing some changes with this or
660         * other component-editing methods (like {@link #protanUp(float, float)} or {@link #darken(float, float)}), you
661         * may want to call {@link #limitToGamut(float)} to make sure the color can be rendered correctly.
662         *
663         * @see #tritanDown(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color less natural
664         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
665         * @param change how much to change start to a natural color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a more natural result
666         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a more natural color
667         */
668        public static float tritanUp(final float start, final float change) {
669                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), t = s >>> 16 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFE00FFFF;
670                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (t + (0xFF - t) * change) << 16 & 0xFF0000) | other);
671        }
672
673        /**
674         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards an "artificial" color (between blue and purple) by change.
675         * While change should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully artificial), start should be a packed color, as
676         * from {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary
677         * Colors, and is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp
678         * towards a more artificial color. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the
679         * alpha and intensity of start as-is.
680         * This method does not necessarily keep the resulting color in-gamut; after performing some changes with this or
681         * other component-editing methods (like {@link #protanUp(float, float)} or {@link #darken(float, float)}), you
682         * may want to call {@link #limitToGamut(float)} to make sure the color can be rendered correctly.
683         *
684         * @see #tritanUp(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color less artificial
685         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
686         * @param change how much to change start to a bolder color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a more artificial result
687         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a more artificial color
688         */
689        public static float tritanDown(final float start, final float change) {
690                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), t = s >>> 16 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFE00FFFF;
691                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (t * (1f - change)) & 0xFF) << 16 | other);
692        }
693
694        /**
695         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards that color made opaque by change. While change should be
696         * between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return start with full alpha), start should be a packed color, as from
697         * {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
698         * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp
699         * towards transparent. This won't change the intensity, protan, or tritan of the color.
700         * @see #fade(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more translucent
701         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
702         * @param change how much to go from start toward opaque, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to opaque
703         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and its opaque version
704         */
705        public static float blot(final float start, final float change) {
706                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), opacity = s >>> 24 & 0xFE, other = s & 0x00FFFFFF;
707                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (opacity + (0xFE - opacity) * change) & 0xFE) << 24 | other);
708        }
709
710        /**
711         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards transparent by change. While change should be between 0
712         * (return start as-is) and 1f (return the color with 0 alpha), start should be a packed color, as from
713         * {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors,
714         * and is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards
715         * transparent. This won't change the intensity, protan, or tritan of the color.
716         * @see #blot(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more opaque
717         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
718         * @param change how much to go from start toward transparent, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to transparent
719         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and transparent
720         */
721        public static float fade(final float start, final float change) {
722                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), opacity = s & 0xFE, other = s & 0x00FFFFFF;
723                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (opacity * (1f - change)) & 0xFE) << 24 | other);
724        }
725
726        /**
727         * Brings the chromatic components of {@code start} closer to grayscale by {@code change} (desaturating them). While
728         * change should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully gray), start should be a packed color, as
729         * from {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}. This only changes protan and tritan; it leaves intensity and alpha
730         * alone, unlike {@link #lessenChange(float, float)}, which usually changes intensity.
731         * @see #enrich(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more saturated
732         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
733         * @param change how much to change start to a desaturated color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a less saturated result
734         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a desaturated color
735         */
736        public static float dullen(final float start, final float change) {
737                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start);
738                return ipt((s & 0xFF) / 255f,
739                                ((s >>> 8 & 0xFF) / 255f - 0.5f) * (1f - change) + 0.5f,
740                                ((s >>> 16 & 0xFF) / 255f - 0.5f) * (1f - change) + 0.5f,
741                                (s >>> 25) / 127f);
742        }
743
744        /**
745         * Pushes the chromatic components of {@code start} away from grayscale by change (saturating them). While change
746         * should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return maximally saturated), start should be a packed color, as
747         * from {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}. This usually changes only protan and tritan, but higher values for
748         * {@code change} can force the color out of the gamut, which this corrects using
749         * {@link #limitToGamut(float, float, float, float)} (and that can change intensity somewhat). If the color stays
750         * in-gamut, then intensity won't change; alpha never changes.
751         * @see #dullen(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color less saturated
752         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
753         * @param change how much to change start to a saturated color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a more saturated result
754         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a saturated color
755         */
756        public static float enrich(final float start, final float change) {
757                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start);
758                return limitToGamut((s & 0xFF) / 255f,
759                                ((s >>> 8 & 0xFF) / 255f - 0.5f) * (1f + change) + 0.5f,
760                                ((s >>> 16 & 0xFF) / 255f - 0.5f) * (1f + change) + 0.5f,
761                                (s >>> 25) / 127f);
762        }
763
764
765        /**
766         * Given a packed float IPT color {@code mainColor} and another IPT color that it should be made to contrast with,
767         * gets a packed float IPT color with roughly inverted intnsity but the same chromatic channels and opacity (P and T
768         * are likely to be clamped if the result gets close to white or black). This won't ever produce black or other very
769         * dark colors, and also has a gap in the range it produces for intensity values between 0.5 and 0.55. That allows
770         * most of the colors this method produces to contrast well as a foreground when displayed on a background of
771         * {@code contrastingColor}, or vice versa. This will leave the intensity unchanged if the chromatic channels of the
772         * contrastingColor and those of the mainColor are already very different. This has nothing to do with the contrast
773         * channel of the tweak in ColorfulBatch; where that part of the tweak can make too-similar lightness values further
774         * apart by just a little, this makes a modification on {@code mainColor} to maximize its lightness difference from
775         * {@code contrastingColor} without losing its other qualities.
776         * @param mainColor a packed float color, as produced by {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}; this is the color that will be adjusted
777         * @param contrastingColor a packed float color, as produced by {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}; the adjusted mainColor will contrast with this
778         * @return a different IPT packed float color, based on mainColor but with potentially very different lightness
779         */
780        public static float inverseLightness(final float mainColor, final float contrastingColor)
781        {
782                final int bits = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(mainColor),
783                                contrastBits = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(contrastingColor),
784                                i = (bits & 0xff),
785                                p = (bits >>> 8 & 0xff),
786                                t = (bits >>> 16 & 0xff),
787                                ci = (contrastBits & 0xff),
788                                cp = (contrastBits >>> 8 & 0xff),
789                                ct = (contrastBits >>> 16 & 0xff);
790                if((p - cp) * (p - cp) + (t - ct) * (t - ct) >= 0x10000)
791                        return mainColor;
792                return ipt(ci < 128 ? i * (0.45f / 255f) + 0.55f : 0.5f - i * (0.45f / 255f), p / 255f, t / 255f, 0x1.0p-8f * (bits >>> 24));
793        }
794
795        /**
796         * Given a packed float IPT_HQ color {@code mainColor} and another IPT_HQ color that it should be made to contrast
797         * with, gets a packed float IPT_HQ color with I that should be quite different from {@code contrastingColor}'s I,
798         * but the same chromatic channels and opacity (A and B are likely to be clamped if the result gets close to white
799         * or black). This allows most of the colors this method produces to contrast well as a foreground when displayed on
800         * a background of {@code contrastingColor}, or vice versa.
801         * <br>
802         * This is similar to {@link #inverseLightness(float, float)}, but is considerably simpler, and this method will
803         * change the lightness of mainColor when the two given colors have close lightness but distant chroma. Because it
804         * averages the original I of mainColor with the modified one, this tends to not produce harsh color changes.
805         * @param mainColor a packed IPT_HQ float color; this is the color that will be adjusted
806         * @param contrastingColor a packed IPT_HQ float color; the adjusted mainColor will contrast with the I of this
807         * @return a different packed IPT_HQ float color, based on mainColor but typically with different lightness
808         */
809        public static float differentiateLightness(final float mainColor, final float contrastingColor)
810        {
811                final int main = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(mainColor), contrast = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(contrastingColor);
812                return limitToGamut(BitConversion.intBitsToFloat((main & 0xFEFFFF00) | (contrast + 128 & 0xFF) + (main & 0xFF) >>> 1));
813        }
814
815        /**
816         * Pretty simple; adds 0.5 to the given color's I and wraps it around if it would go above 1.0, then averages that
817         * with the original I. This means light colors become darker, and dark colors become lighter, with almost all
818         * results in the middle-range of possible lightness.
819         * @param mainColor a packed IPT_HQ float color
820         * @return a different packed IPT_HQ float color, with its I channel changed and limited to the correct gamut
821         */
822        public static float offsetLightness(final float mainColor) {
823                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(mainColor);
824                return limitToGamut(BitConversion.intBitsToFloat((decoded & 0xFEFFFF00) | (decoded + 128 & 0xFF) + (decoded & 0xFF) >>> 1));
825        }
826
827        /**
828         * Makes the additive IPT color stored in {@code color} cause less of a change when used as a tint, as if it were
829         * mixed with neutral gray. When {@code fraction} is 1.0, this returns color unchanged; when fraction is 0.0, it
830         * returns {@link Palette#GRAY}, and when it is in-between 0.0 and 1.0 it returns something between the two. This is
831         * meant for things like area of effect abilities that make smaller color changes toward their periphery.
832         * @param color a color that should have its tinting effect potentially weakened
833         * @param fraction how much of {@code color} should be kept, from 0.0 to 1.0
834         * @return an IPT float color between gray and {@code color}
835         */
836        public static float lessenChange(final float color, float fraction) {
837                final int e = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(color),
838                                is = 0x80, ps = 0x80, ts = 0x80,
839                                ie = (e & 0xFF), pe = (e >>> 8) & 0xFF, te = (e >>> 16) & 0xFF, ae = e >>> 24 & 0xFE;
840                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (is + fraction * (ie - is)) & 0xFF)
841                                | (((int) (ps + fraction * (pe - ps)) & 0xFF) << 8)
842                                | (((int) (ts + fraction * (te - ts)) & 0xFF) << 16)
843                                | (ae << 24));
844        }
845
846        /**
847         * Makes a quasi-randomly-edited variant on the given {@code color}, allowing typically a small amount of
848         * {@code variance} (such as 0.05 to 0.25) between the given color and what this can return. The {@code seed} should
849         * be different each time this is called, and can be obtained from a random number generator to make the colors more
850         * random, or can be incremented on each call. If the seed is only incremented or decremented, then this shouldn't
851         * produce two similar colors in a row unless variance is very small. The variance affects the I, P, and T of the
852         * generated color, and each of those channels can go up or down by the given variance as long as the total distance
853         * isn't greater than the variance (this considers P and T extra-wide, going from -1 to 1, while I goes from 0 to 1,
854         * but only internally for measuring distance).
855         * @param color a packed float color, as produced by {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}
856         * @param seed a long seed that should be different on each call; should not be 0
857         * @param variance max amount of difference between the given color and the generated color; always less than 1
858         * @return a generated packed float color that should be at least somewhat different from {@code color}
859         */
860        public static float randomEdit(final float color, long seed, final float variance) {
861                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(color);
862                final float i = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
863                final float p = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
864                final float t = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
865                final float limit = variance * variance;
866                float dist, x, y, z;
867                for (int j = 0; j < 50; j++) {
868                        x = (((seed * 0xD1B54A32D192ED03L >>> 41) - 0x7FFFFFp-1f) * 0x1p-22f) * variance;
869                        y = (((seed * 0xABC98388FB8FAC03L >>> 41) - 0x7FFFFFp-1f) * 0x1p-22f) * variance;
870                        z = (((seed * 0x8CB92BA72F3D8DD7L >>> 41) - 0x7FFFFFp-1f) * 0x1p-22f) * variance;
871                        seed += 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L;
872                        dist = x * x + y * y + z * z;
873                        if(dist <= limit && inGamut(x += i, y = (p + y) * 0.5f + 0.5f, z = (t + z) * 0.5f + 0.5f))
874                                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat((decoded & 0xFE000000) | ((int)(z * 255.5f) << 16 & 0xFF0000)
875                                        | ((int)(y * 255.5f) << 8 & 0xFF00) | (int)(x * 255.5f));
876                }
877                return color;
878        }
879
880        /**
881         * Returns true if the given packed float color, as IPT, is valid to convert losslessly back to RGBA. 
882         * @param packed a packed float color as IPT
883         * @return true if the given packed float color can be converted back and forth to RGBA
884         */
885        public static boolean inGamut(final float packed)
886        {
887                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
888                final float i = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
889                final float p = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
890                final float t = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
891                final float l = reverseTransform(i + 0.097569f * p + 0.205226f * t);
892                final float m = reverseTransform(i + -0.11388f * p + 0.133217f * t);
893                final float s = reverseTransform(i + 0.032615f * p + -0.67689f * t);
894
895                final float r = 5.432622f * l + -4.67910f * m + 0.246257f * s;
896                if(r < 0f || r > 1.0f) return false;
897                final float g = -1.10517f * l + 2.311198f * m + -0.20588f * s;
898                if(g < 0f || g > 1.0f) return false;
899                final float b = 0.028104f * l + -0.19466f * m + 1.166325f * s;
900                return (b >= 0f && b <= 1.0f);
901        }
902        /**
903         * Returns true if the given IPT values are valid to convert losslessly back to RGBA. 
904         * @param i intensity channel, as a float from 0 to 1
905         * @param p protan channel, as a float from 0 to 1
906         * @param t tritan channel, as a float from 0 to 1
907         * @return true if the given packed float color can be converted back and forth to RGBA
908         */
909        public static boolean inGamut(float i, float p, float t)
910        {
911                p = (p - 0.5f) * 2f;
912                t = (t - 0.5f) * 2f;
913                final float l = reverseTransform(i + 0.097569f * p + 0.205226f * t);
914                final float m = reverseTransform(i + -0.11388f * p + 0.133217f * t);
915                final float s = reverseTransform(i + 0.032615f * p + -0.67689f * t);
916
917                final float r = 5.432622f * l + -4.67910f * m + 0.246257f * s;
918                if(r < 0f || r > 1.0f) return false;
919                final float g = -1.10517f * l + 2.311198f * m + -0.20588f * s;
920                if(g < 0f || g > 1.0f) return false;
921                final float b = 0.028104f * l + -0.19466f * m + 1.166325f * s;
922                return (b >= 0f && b <= 1.0f);
923        }
924
925        /**
926         * Iteratively checks whether the given IPT color is in-gamut, and either brings the color closer to grayscale if it
927         * isn't in-gamut, or returns it as soon as it is in-gamut. Maintains the intensity of the color, only bringing
928         * protan and tritan closer to grayscale.
929         * @param packed a packed float color in IPT format; often this color is not in-gamut
930         * @return the first color this finds that is between the given IPT color and grayscale, and is in-gamut
931         * @see #inGamut(float) You can use inGamut() if you just want to check whether a color is in-gamut.
932         */
933        public static float limitToGamut(final float packed) {
934                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
935                final float i = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
936                final float p = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
937                final float t = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
938                float p2 = p, t2 = t;
939                for (int attempt = 31; attempt >= 0; attempt--) {
940                        final float l = reverseTransform(i + 0.097569f * p2 + 0.205226f * t2);
941                        final float m = reverseTransform(i + -0.11388f * p2 + 0.133217f * t2);
942                        final float s = reverseTransform(i + 0.032615f * p2 + -0.67689f * t2);
943
944                        final float r = 5.432622f * l + -4.67910f * m + 0.246257f * s;
945                        final float g = -1.10517f * l + 2.311198f * m + -0.20588f * s;
946                        final float b = 0.028104f * l + -0.19466f * m + 1.166325f * s;
947                        if(r >= 0f && r <= 1f && g >= 0f && g <= 1f && b >= 0f && b <= 1f)
948                                break;
949                        final float progress = attempt * 0x1p-5f;
950                        p2 = MathTools.lerp(0, p, progress);
951                        t2 = MathTools.lerp(0, t, progress);
952                }
953                return ipt(i, p2 * 0.5f + 0.5f, t2 * 0.5f + 0.5f, (decoded >>> 25) / 127f);
954        }
955
956        /**
957         * Iteratively checks whether the given IPT color is in-gamut, and either brings the color closer to grayscale if it
958         * isn't in-gamut, or returns it as soon as it is in-gamut. Maintains the intensity of the color, only bringing
959         * protan and tritan closer to grayscale. This always produces an opaque color.
960         * @param i intensity component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
961         * @param p protan component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
962         * @param t tritan component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
963         * @return the first color this finds that is between the given IPT color and grayscale, and is in-gamut
964         * @see #inGamut(float, float, float)  You can use inGamut() if you just want to check whether a color is in-gamut.
965         */
966        public static float limitToGamut(float i, float p, float t) {
967                return limitToGamut(i, p, t, 1f);
968        }
969        /**
970         * Iteratively checks whether the given IPT color is in-gamut, and either brings the color closer to grayscale if it
971         * isn't in-gamut, or returns it as soon as it is in-gamut. Maintains the intensity of the color, only bringing
972         * protan and tritan closer to grayscale.
973         * @param i intensity component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
974         * @param p protan component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
975         * @param t tritan component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
976         * @param a alpha component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
977         * @return the first color this finds that is between the given IPT color and grayscale, and is in-gamut
978         * @see #inGamut(float, float, float)  You can use inGamut() if you just want to check whether a color is in-gamut.
979         */
980        public static float limitToGamut(float i, float p, float t, float a) {
981                float i2 = Math.min(Math.max(i, 0f), 1f);
982                float p2 = p = Math.min(Math.max((p - 0.5f) * 2f, -1f), 1f);
983                float t2 = t = Math.min(Math.max((t - 0.5f) * 2f, -1f), 1f);
984                a = Math.min(Math.max(a, 0f), 1f);
985                for (int attempt = 31; attempt >= 0; attempt--) {
986                        final float l = reverseTransform(i2 + 0.097569f * p2 + 0.205226f * t2);
987                        final float m = reverseTransform(i2 + -0.11388f * p2 + 0.133217f * t2);
988                        final float s = reverseTransform(i2 + 0.032615f * p2 + -0.67689f * t2);
989
990                        final float r = 5.432622f * l + -4.67910f * m + 0.246257f * s;
991                        final float g = -1.10517f * l + 2.311198f * m + -0.20588f * s;
992                        final float b = 0.028104f * l + -0.19466f * m + 1.166325f * s;
993                        if(r >= 0f && r <= 1f && g >= 0f && g <= 1f && b >= 0f && b <= 1f)
994                                break;
995                        final float progress = attempt * 0x1p-5f;
996                        p2 = MathTools.lerp(0, p, progress);
997                        t2 = MathTools.lerp(0, t, progress);
998                }
999                return ipt(i2, p2 * 0.5f + 0.5f, t2 * 0.5f + 0.5f, a);
1000        }
1001        /**
1002         * Given a packed float IPT_HQ color, this edits its intensity, protan, tritan, and alpha channels by adding the
1003         * corresponding "add" parameter and then clamping. This returns a different float value (of course, the given float
1004         * can't be edited in-place). You can give a value of 0 for any "add" parameter you want to stay unchanged. This
1005         * clamps the resulting color to remain in-gamut, so it should be safe to convert it back to RGBA.
1006         * @param encoded a packed float IPT_HQ color
1007         * @param addI how much to add to the intensity channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
1008         * @param addP how much to add to the protan channel; typically in the -2 to 2 range
1009         * @param addT how much to add to the tritan channel; typically in the -2 to 2 range
1010         * @param addAlpha how much to add to the alpha channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
1011         * @return a packed float IPT_HQ color with the requested edits applied to {@code encoded}
1012         */
1013        public static float editIPT(float encoded, float addI, float addP, float addT, float addAlpha) {
1014                return editIPT(encoded, addI, addP, addT, addAlpha, 1f, 1f, 1f, 1f);
1015        }
1016        /**
1017         * Given a packed float IPT_HQ color, this edits its intensity, protan, tritan, and alpha channels by first
1018         * multiplying each channel by the corresponding "mul" parameter and then adding the corresponding "add" parameter,
1019         * before clamping. This means the intensity value is multiplied by {@code mulI}, then has {@code addI} added, and
1020         * then is clamped to the normal range for intensity (0 to 1). This returns a different float value (of course, the
1021         * given float can't be edited in-place). You can give a value of 0 for any "add" parameter you want to stay
1022         * unchanged, or a value of 1 for any "mul" parameter that shouldn't change. Note that this manipulates protan and
1023         * tritan in the -1 to 1 range, so if you multiply by a small number like {@code 0.25f}, then this will produce a
1024         * less-saturated color, and if you multiply by a larger number like {@code 4f}, then you will get a much
1025         * more-saturated color. This clamps the resulting color to remain in-gamut, so it should be safe to convert it back
1026         * to RGBA.
1027         * @param encoded a packed float IPT_HQ color
1028         * @param addI how much to add to the intensity channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
1029         * @param addP how much to add to the protan channel; typically in the -2 to 2 range
1030         * @param addT how much to add to the tritan channel; typically in the -2 to 2 range
1031         * @param addAlpha how much to add to the alpha channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
1032         * @param mulI how much to multiply the intensity channel by; should be non-negative
1033         * @param mulP how much to multiply the protan channel by; usually non-negative (not always)
1034         * @param mulT how much to multiply the tritan channel by; usually non-negative (not always)
1035         * @param mulAlpha how much to multiply the alpha channel by; should be non-negative
1036         * @return a packed float IPT_HQ color with the requested edits applied to {@code encoded}
1037         */
1038        public static float editIPT(float encoded, float addI, float addP, float addT, float addAlpha,
1039                                                                float mulI, float mulP, float mulT, float mulAlpha) {
1040                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
1041                float i = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
1042                float p = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
1043                float t = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
1044                float alpha = (decoded >>> 25) / 127f;
1045
1046                float i2 = Math.min(Math.max(i * mulI + addI, 0f), 1f);
1047                float p2 = p = Math.min(Math.max(p * mulP + addP, -1f), 1f);
1048                float t2 = t = Math.min(Math.max(t * mulT + addT, -1f), 1f);
1049                alpha = Math.min(Math.max(alpha * mulAlpha + addAlpha, 0f), 1f);
1050                for (int attempt = 31; attempt >= 0; attempt--) {
1051                        final float l = reverseTransform(i2 + 0.097569f * p2 + 0.205226f * t2);
1052                        final float m = reverseTransform(i2 + -0.11388f * p2 + 0.133217f * t2);
1053                        final float s = reverseTransform(i2 + 0.032615f * p2 + -0.67689f * t2);
1054
1055                        final float r = 5.432622f * l + -4.67910f * m + 0.246257f * s;
1056                        final float g = -1.10517f * l + 2.311198f * m + -0.20588f * s;
1057                        final float b = 0.028104f * l + -0.19466f * m + 1.166325f * s;
1058                        if(r >= 0f && r <= 1f && g >= 0f && g <= 1f && b >= 0f && b <= 1f)
1059                                break;
1060                        final float progress = attempt * 0x1p-5f;
1061                        p2 = MathTools.lerp(0, p, progress);
1062                        t2 = MathTools.lerp(0, t, progress);
1063                }
1064                return ipt(i2, p2 * 0.5f + 0.5f, t2 * 0.5f + 0.5f, alpha);
1065        }
1066
1067        /**
1068         * Produces a random packed float color that is always in-gamut (and opaque) and should be uniformly distributed.
1069         * @param random a Random object (preferably a subclass of Random, like {@link com.github.tommyettinger.random.LaserRandom})
1070         * @return a packed float color that is always in-gamut
1071         */
1072        public static float randomColor(Random random) {
1073                float i = random.nextFloat();
1074                float p = random.nextFloat();
1075                float t = random.nextFloat();
1076                while (!inGamut(i, p, t)) {
1077                        i = random.nextFloat();
1078                        p = random.nextFloat();
1079                        t = random.nextFloat();
1080                }
1081                return ipt(i, p, t, 1f);
1082        }
1083
1084        /**
1085         * Produces a random packed float color that is always in-gamut (and opaque) and should be uniformly distributed.
1086         * This is named differently from {@link #randomColor(Random)} to avoid confusion when a class both extends Random
1087         * and EnhancedRandom.
1088         * @param random any subclass of juniper's EnhancedRandom, such as a
1089         * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.random.DistinctRandom} or
1090         * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.random.FourWheelRandom}
1091         * @return a packed float color that is always in-gamut
1092         */
1093        public static float randomizedColor(EnhancedRandom random) {
1094                float i = random.nextFloat();
1095                float p = random.nextFloat();
1096                float t = random.nextFloat();
1097                while (!inGamut(i, p, t)) {
1098                        i = random.nextFloat();
1099                        p = random.nextFloat();
1100                        t = random.nextFloat();
1101                }
1102                return ipt(i, p, t, 1f);
1103        }
1104
1105}
